{
  "paper_metadata": {
    "title": "Examining the Impacts of Framed Transfers and Agricultural Extension Services Among Smallholder Farmers in Malawi",
    "matches_expected_title": "NO"
  },
  "program_information": {
    "program_name": "National Smallholder Farmers' Association of Malawi (NASFAM) Program",
    "country": "Malawi",
    "region": null,
    "target_population": "Smallholder farmers"
  },
  "intervention_components": {
    "component_a_cash_support": {
      "component_a_present": true,
      "cash_support_type": "framed cash transfers",
      "cash_amount": "US$36 at planting, $22 midseason, and $26 at harvest",
      "cash_frequency": "three transfers during the agricultural season",
      "is_loan_or_credit": "NO",
      "cash_evidence_citation": "For the transfer treatment, farmers were randomly allocated to a control group that received no transfers; a cash group that received a series of three framed cash transfers, 1 at planting (US$36), 2 midseason ($22), and harvest ($26); and an input group that received transfers of equivalent value."
    },
    "component_b_assets": {
      "component_b_present": true,
      "assets_provided": ["seeds", "hoes", "inoculant", "storage sacks"],
      "direct_provision": "YES",
      "assets_evidence_citation": "Farmers were randomly allocated to a control group that received no transfers; a cash group that received a series of three framed cash transfers [...] and an input group that received transfers of equivalent value, of which approximately 50 percent were given in kind (seed, hoes, inoculant, storage sacks)."
    }
  },
  "study_characteristics": {
    "outcomes_measured": [
      "crop production",
      "yields",
      "productive investments",
      "knowledge and use of agricultural practices",
      "farm management indicators",
      "household assets",
      "savings",
      "food consumption",
      "nonfood consumption"
    ],
    "outcomes_evidence_citation": "We examine program impacts by measuring impacts first of the transfers, then of the intensive extension services, and finally of their interaction. [...] Finally, we consider the welfare impacts for each set of interventions by examining total household assets and savings, as well as food and nonfood consumption aggregates.",
    "study_design": "Randomized Controlled Trial (RCT)",
    "design_evidence_citation": "This study examines a cross-cutting randomized controlled trial with a transfer arm that offers either cash or in-kind transfers and an agricultural training arm that tests an intensive agricultural extension model.",
    "is_review_or_policy_analysis": false,
    "publication_year": null,
    "study_conducted_year": "2015-2017",
    "sample_size": 1200,
    "completed": true
  },

    "qualitative_evidence_citation": null,
    "has_cost_data": false,
    "cost_mentions": null,
    "cost_evidence_citation": null
  },
  "evidence_citations": {
    "program_name_citation": "We implemented the program in partnership with the National Smallholder Farmers' Association of Malawi (NASFAM) and worked with approximately 1,200 households randomly allocated at the farmer club level (120 clubs in total) to the transfer and agricultural training treatments.",
    "country_citation": "We implemented the program in partnership with the National Smallholder Farmers' Association of Malawi (NASFAM) and worked with approximately 1,200 households randomly allocated at the farmer club level (120 clubs in total) to the transfer and agricultural training treatments.",
    "target_population_citation": "Globally, poverty is heavily concentrated in rural areas and among those who rely on agriculture for their livelihoods. [...] This paper examines the impacts of an intervention that combines two popular elements of such programs: transfers and agricultural training."
  }
